Scientific Computing and Imaging Institute, University of Utah

The Scientific Computing and Imaging (SCI) research group was founded in 1994 by Drs. Chris Johnson and Rob MacLeod along with five graduate students. In 1996, they became the Center for Scientific Computing and Imaging and in 2000, the SCI Institute. The Scientific Computing and Imaging Institute is now one of eight permanent research institutes at the University of Utah and home to over 200 faculty, students, and staff.

Education: Activities and societies: Biomechanics research group
Mechanobiology; Cell mechanics; Modeling and simulations

I was involved in computational multiscale modeling of actin filaments and actin assemblies. At the molecular level of description, I was focused on the interactions among monomers along the actin filament, pointing out what specific residues rearrangments and in what particular regions of the actin filament are able to induce changes in the mechanics of the protein. At the microscale, I investigated the changes in mechanical properties of active actin networks as a response to variations of stiffness of the extra-cellular matrix. Always at the microscale, I investigated the mechanisms of formation of different actin assemblies, their morphological and mechanical properties, with emphasis on stress fibers and focal adhesions.
Experience: I am interested in the mechanistic regulation of integrin activation in relation with ligand binding and clustering. Integrin activation presents biological, chemical, physical, and mechanical aspects. I believe that a multiscale computational framework can be used to elucidate out-of-equilibrium integrin activation by incorporating the different aspects that we know about integrin dynamics from biological, chemical, biophysical and mechanical characterization. At the university of Chicago, I am developing such a framework.
I write algorithms to simulate actomyosin self-organization. I am instructor of the course of computational physics. I supervise undergaduates in semester and summer research projects.
I was using computational models to characterize strain stiffening of passively and actively crosslinked actin network.

Education: Information Theory, Caching Networks, Coding Theory, Algorithms, Interference Networks
Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications
Experience: Over the past decade, advances in storage, chip and software technologies have enabled the development of systems that are distributed, miniaturized and equipped with large storage, powerful computational, communication, and sensing capabilities, such as distributed storage and cloud computing platforms, embedded and mobile systems. One promising prospect of this technological advancement is its potential for seamlessly integrating the intelligences of information storing, computing, and transmitting. My research interests and efforts span the areas of fundamental limits and practical designs of (wireless and wireline) caching networks, distributed storage and computing systems, (statistical) signal/data processing, stochastic network optimization, and wire- less communications. I am particularly interested in developing caching, (distributed) information processing and transmitting technologies that significantly improve the performance of current systems. My work covers the entire spectrum of research in this domain: from theoretically studying the fundamental limits to practically developing and implementing low-complexity algorithms, from designing information placements techniques, to advancing information processing and delivery technologies, to developing novel applications, to evaluating these applications through real-world deployment studies.

Designing Visually Accessible Spaces- NIH RESEARCH PROJECT- industry liaison

DEVA has developed graphical prototype tools that can predict visibility, particularly low vision visibility. The architectural professions can use these tools during the design phase of a project. If a potential hazard (steps for example) are analyses as not visible, the designer can change lighting, materials and or geometry to iteratively solve the visibility challenge. The work is a collaboration between University of Minnesota, Utah and Indiana, including specialists in low vision, computational vision, computer and cognitive science, lighting visualization and lighting design.
